Summary: The proposal 'CausalBench' aims to enhance causal reasoning in AI by integrating dynamic causal structures with neural counterfactual predictors. It addresses the limitations of static causal graphs and inadequate counterfactual reasoning in existing models through a three-part framework: dynamic causal graph learning, intervention-invariant representations, and counterfactual dynamics simulation. The experiment plan includes validation on synthetic benchmarks, real-world datasets, and high-dimensional data like fMRI time-series, culminating in real-world deployment in clinical trial simulations.
Strengths: Innovative combination of dynamic causal graph learning and counterfactual dynamics.
Detailed and comprehensive experiment plan covering synthetic and real-world datasets.
Strong grounding in existing literature and plausible hypothesis.
Weaknesses: Lacks detailed discussion on computational resources and potential bottlenecks.
Feasibility concerns regarding scaling to high-dimensional data like fMRI time-series.
Limited risk assessment and mitigation strategies for practical deployment in clinical settings.
Validation plan could benefit from more detailed ablation studies.
Questions: What computational resources will be required for scaling to high-dimensional data like fMRI time-series?
How will the model handle noisy or incomplete data in real-world clinical settings?
What are the potential bottlenecks in deploying the model in clinical trial simulations?
Can you provide more details on the ablation studies planned to evaluate the contributions of each component of the framework?
Limitations: Scalability to high-dimensional data may be challenging.
Practical deployment in clinical settings may face regulatory and ethical hurdles.
The model's performance may degrade with noisy or incomplete data.
